Award.AwardTitle: Supersolidity and the Supersolid to Normal Solid Transition
Award.AbstractNarration:
Technical Abstract.

The observation of superfluid-like behavior in bulk solid helium and solid helium confined in porous media in the P.I.'s laboratory has been replicated in a dozen other laboratories. Quantum Monte Carlo simulations suggest superfluidity is not possible in a perfect crystal but dislocation lines may be superfluid. Shear modulus measurements indicate that superfluidity in solid helium or supersolidity is the consequence of a stiffened network of interconnected dislocation lines. This model however, cannot explain the results in porous media since it is difficult to envision dislocation lines inside a pore of a few nm. Three questions will be addressed in this project. One set of experiments will determine if supersolidity is possible in a perfect crystal with little or no dislocation lines. Secondly, heat capacity, thermal conductivity measurements will be carried out to determine how supersolidity in porous media is different from that in bulk solid. Lastly torsional oscillator measurements will be made to determine the spatial extent of quantum phase coherence in a supersolid system. The experiments are exceptionally challenging hence providing an excellent training ground for the post-doctoral, graduate and undergraduate students in the project. The P.I. has a very strong and sustained record in training students for successful scientific careers in academia and in industrial and government laboratories

Non-technical Abstract

When liquid helium is cooled below -271 Celsius, or 2 K above absolute zero, it enters the superfluid state with zero viscosity allowing it to flow relative to the walls of a container with no friction. What this means is that if a container is being oscillated back and forth, the superfluid inside will sit perfectly still. Like superconductivity, superfluidity is a manifestation of quantum mechanics at macroscopic scales. In 2004, the P.I. and one of his former student found evidence that below 0.2K, a small fraction (on the order of 1%) of a solid helium sample would remain stationary when its container is being oscillated. This experiment, since replicated in a dozen laboratories worldwide, indicates the existence of superfluidity in a solid, more conveniently called supersolidity. The discovery of this new state of matter has created considerable excitement in the physics community and beyond. An outstanding question of the phenomenon is whether supersolidity is possible in a perfect helium crystal or it requires the presence of defects such as dislocation lines in the crystal. The experiments proposed in the project are designed to resolve this question and will be carried out by post-doctoral, graduate and undergraduate students. The P.I. has a very strong and sustained record in training students for successful scientific careers in academia, industrial and government laboratories.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Owing to its light mass and weak interatomic attraction, liquid 4He stays in the liquid phase down to absolute zero, i.e. 0 K  or -273 C. Freezing into the solid phase does not commence until a pressure equivalent to 25 times the ambient atmospheric pressure ( 25 atm) is applied. A even more remarkable phenomenon is found when the liquid is cooled below 2.176K, specficially, it transforms from a normal liquid to a superfluid. In the superfluid state, liquid 4He can flow with no loss of energy. If the superfluid is set into circular motion inside a container, it will never stop! Conversely, if a container is filled with superfluid and if the container is set into rotational or oscillatory motion, the superfluid inside the container will stay motionless. This phenomenon is related to the fact that 4He atoms are Bosons and at sufficiently low temperature, according to quantum mechanics, the 4He atoms lose their indvidual identities and undergo Bose-Einsten condensation into the lowest quantum state and behaves like a single giant atom which cannot lose any energy. 

Interestingly there is no theoretical principle that forbits such a superfluid state to exist even in solid 4He ! The reason is again the low mass and weak interatomic attraction. X-ray studies showed that the 4He atoms in the crystalline solid phase spend 28% of the time away from their 'assigned' sites. If the fluctuations of these 4He atoms from their assigned sites are coherent or 'in phase', supersolidity is found. In 2004, Kim and Chan at Penn State searched for such evidence of supersolidity. They introduce into a torsion cell ( ie, a small container) and then set the torsion cell in oscillatory motion against a rigid torsion rod. When this torsional oscillator is cooled below 0.1K, they found a small increase in the resonent frequency of the oscillation. A natural explantion of the decrease in resonant frequency is that a small fraction of the solid 4He is no longer oscillating with the torsion cell. In other words, it showed apparent signature of supersolidity. This result was replicated in 11 other laboratories around the world.

However, after a decade of further studies, it was found that 3He impurities which exist naturally in 4He tend to bind to the dislocation lines in solid 4He below 0.1K and stiffen the solid sample in the torsion cell. If the torsion cells are not infinitely rigid, this stiffening of the solid 4He sample increases the rigidity of the torsion cell which also can cause an increase in the resonant frequency of the oscillation, micmicking the onset of supersolidity.

In this project we carried out measurements in extraordinarily rigid torsion cells that substantially reduce the 3He stiffening effect. The upshot of these measurement is that we no longer see any measureable increase in the resonant frequency of the oscillator below 0.1K. This means the signal that was attributed to supersolidity by Kim and Chan and the other 11 laboratories are due to the 3He stiffening effect. Our studies also led to the conclusion if supersoldity exists in solid 4He,it is less than 4 parts in 106 . This is disappointing but these studies finally brought clarity to the subject of supersolidity. It is interesting that our studies inspired the search which resulted in possible evidence of supersolidity in cold atomic gases. 

Our work in supersoldity also inspired an experiment that shows the observation of superfluidlike mass flow through solid 4He when the solid samples are sandwiched between two superfluid leads. The superfluid leads are porous Vycor glass cylinders. Inside the narrow pores of the Vycor glass (with diameter of only 7 nm), helium stays in the liquid phase up to 35 atm in pressure thus enabling an experimental topology of a superfluid-solid-superfluid sandwich at pressure between 25 and 35 atm. It was proposed that the mass flow takes place along the dislcoation lines in solid 4He with superfluid cores. We made measurements on solid samples of only 8 micrometer in thickness sandwiched between the flat surfaces of the two opposing porous Vycor glass cylinders. We showed that mass flow is always found from the freezing pressure at 25 atm up to 30 atm with a concomitant decrease in onset temeprature from 1 to 0.25K. Since the thickness of the solid sample is short compare with the characteristic length of the dislocation line network, we can conclude that the mass flow takes place along the array of one-dimensional dislocation lines. This is an interesting realization of one-dimensional mass transport of a quantum system.
